title: HOT OR NOT: Katarina Johnson-Thompson shines while Evander Holyfield has a lot to lose
text:
It's Hot or Not time again as Sportsmail's Riath Al-Samarrai reveals what's been making him feel warm and what's been leaving him cold this week.

HOT

Katarina Johnson-Thompson

Dina Asher-Smith has taken the limelight for brilliant gold and silver medals but the finest performance in the World Championships was delivered by heptathlete Johnson-Thompson.

After disappointment at the Rio Olympics and two previous world championships, most athletes wouldn't be able to walk seven paces in an arena, let alone crush an Olympic champion and break a national record.

Katarina Johnson-Thompson has been hugely impressive at the World Championships

Andy Murray

Piece by piece, he is putting himself back together. On Friday, five weeks after playing a Challenger event in Mallorca, he was causing problems for world No 5 Dominic Thiem in the China Open.

He lost but the signs point to another run to the top end of the game.

Andy Murray may have lost to Dominic Thiem but he is heading back to the top of the game

Tammy Abraham

A first Champions League goal on his birthday and a call-up to the England squad.

Funny what can happen when young players are given the opportunity to play. Plenty of good can come out of Chelsea's transfer ban.

It was an excellent week for Tammy Abraham, who was named in the England squad

NOT

IAAF

However Seb Coe tries to justify it, and he has tried very hard, taking the World Athletics Championships to Doha was a dough-headed idea.

Runner collapsing in the marathon, tiny crowds on most nights and a staging too late in the year. At a time when the sport needs to sell itself, it sold out instead.

Taking the World Athletics Championships to Doha was a dough-headed idea

The Hundred

Nothing screams quality quite like a group of cricketers dressed like crisp packets.

Anti-obesity campaigners have had their say on the messages that gives out to children but the sponsors seem to be taking a punt on the public showing mass interest in yet another form of the game.

Nothing screams quality quite like a group of cricketers dressed like crisp packets

Evander Holyfield

Another old man of the ring has come out of retirement for another go. At 56, this is as ludicrous as the recent decision by Nigel Benn to end his 23-year retirement.

It's been eight years since Holyfield fought but, as a living legend of the sport, he has nothing to prove and a lot to lose.
